newsitem.title: GERMANY: German grain intervention offers led by feed rye.
newsitem.headline: German grain intervention offers led by feed rye.

text.p: Some 37,844 tonnes of feed rye was offered into German intervention stores last week after 29,748 tonnes a week earlier, state intervention board BLE data showed on Monday.
Traders said European markets no longer appeared to be requiring feed rye while feed wheat was still sought after.

Barley was offered for intervention in regions far away from key consumption centres in the livestock industry, for example in eastern Germany, where there was also a concentration of feed rye offers.
Some wheat offers were seen in Lower Saxony state.
But totals in the November-May 1996/97 intervention season lag those in the same 95/96 period.
Total grain volumes offered by March 21 totalled 838,777 tonnes compared with 1,593,956 tonnes a year earlier.
The March buying-in price for all grains is 243.68 marks a tonne.
The offers are volumes that were accepted, but have not yet been delivered to stores, by the close last Friday.
Sellers may withdraw offers and BLE may refuse acceptance on quality grounds.
BLE gave the following breakdown in tonnes --
